<h2>What is the tidyverse?</h2>

<ul>
<li>Principles of tidy data</li>
<li>Functions to manipulate data from messy to tidy</li>
<li>Tools for tidy wrangling</li>
<li>Tidy functions to filter, summarize, and modify data (<i>Lesson 6</i>)</li>
</ul>

<hr>
<h2>What are tidy data?</h2>
<p><b>In the formal language of data science</b>: The three normal forms (Codd et al.)<p>
<ol>
<li>First normal (Post-hoc):
<ul>
<li>All rows represent a unique record (primary key)</li>
<li>All values are atomic</li>
<li>Columns are not grouped</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>All columns are unique to the observation event (primary key) -- i.e., do each of the column values describe the observation event? If not, put them in another table.</li>
<li>All columns are non-transitively dependent: No column values are directly dependent on any column except that which defines the observation</li>
</ol>

<h2>What are tidy data?</h2>

<p>In less formal language:</p>
<ul>
<li>Each variable forms a column</li>
<li>Each observation forms a row</li>
<li>Each type of observational unit forms a table</li>
</ul>
<p>Each tidy dataset arranging values into the <b>same</b> structure.</p>
<p>The best way to understand these rules is to look at examples of when they are broken.</p>

<h2>Tidy data: Each variable forms a column</h2>
<h3>Untidy version</h3>
<p>Problem: More than one variable in a column</p>
<p>Problem: One variable split into multiple columns</p>

<h3>Tidy version</h3>

<h2>Tidy data: Each observation forms a row</h2>
<h3>Untidy version</h3>
<p>Problem: More than one observation in a row</p>
<p>Problem: One observation split into multiple rows</p>

<h3>Tidy version</h3>

<h2>Tidy data: Each type of observational unit forms a table</h2>

<h3>Untidy version</h3>
<p>Problem: More than observational unit in a table (most common)</p>
<p>Problem: One observational split provided in multiple tables</p>


<h3>Tidy version</h3>

<h2>Some more rules for tidy data</h2>
<h3>Value format matters</h3>
<p>Why not use standard date formats?</p>
<h3>Why on Earth would you use row names for a data frame?</h3>

<h2>Why use tidy data?</h2>
<p>The same functions and steps can be applied across datasets</p>
<p>Modifications can be applied without modifying each table</p>
<p>Easy filtering and summarizing</p>
<p>Analysist can choose the level of analysis</p>

<h2>Why would you create untidy data?</h2>

<ol>
<li>You like to look at your data</li>
<li>Ease of data entry (Excel?)</li>
<li>You complete a step of wrangling in Excel</li>
<li>Planned redundancy (aka trust issues)</li>
<li>Structuring data for a planned analysis</li>
</ol>
